page.title: 09Wringworthy Farm.(contd.)
page.content: In summer all his cattle are in the fields but in the winter all the young calves are indoors in sheds.The dairy cows are allowed to wander freely in and out of the stockyard and the cowshed.His beef cattle are the male calves of his dairy cows.The female calves he keeps to replace his dairy cows.The beef cattle are kept until their second autumn when they are sold to lowland farmers for fattening as this is a moorland farm and the land is too high for fattening cattle.The beef cattle stay outside all year on his land near Mary Tavy.There is some woodland here so they have some protection in winter.In summer the farmer has silage and hay to cut and calves to feed.In winter the farmer spends most of his day feeding and cleaning out his stock.
